Award.AwardTitle: Revealing Structure via Dynamics: Biological Networks from Protein Folding to Food Webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
A principal goal of biological theory is to understand complex living systems in terms of their parts and the interactions between their parts. In this project, an ecologist, a protein physiologist and a mathematician will collaborate to develop new ways of understanding how highly interconnected biological systems change through time. Specifically, these investigators aim to develop a general theory of linear dynamics on complex biological networks. Surprisingly, a great variety of critically important biological phenomena at a wide range of scales is captured by linear or approximately linear dynamics on complex networks. By applying novel methods for coarse graining biological networks, this project will answer questions such as: how many functionally distinct moving parts does a given system have? How do quantities of interest, such as nutrients or information, move through a highly interconnected network? Which nodes or edges in such a network are the most important for transmission? Can we identify nodes whose removal has the greatest or smallest effect on the performance of the network?

Developing a framework for general linear dynamics on complex biological networks will have a broad and deep impact on our ability to understand, predict and control critically important biological processes at a wide range of scales. In addition, this project will contribute to training students at the undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral level to work across disciplines such as ecology, physiology and mathematics to deepen our understanding of complex biological systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Networks are ubiquitous in biological systems.  In ecology, networks
arise as descriptions of food webs, and also as descriptions of
geographical dispersal of organisms. In the latter case, the vertices of

the network represent different locations (e.g. different habitat patches along a coast) and the edges of the network represent possible routes that  organisms may follow while migrating.  In protein folding, networks arise as a description of the different amino acids making up the protein, with the edges representing which amino acid is connected to which other. In each of these examples, the transitions between states in the network may by more or less stochastic (meaning "random" or "unpredictable"). In ecology, the migration of individuals might be highly predictable, like the north/south migrations of birds with the changing seasons.  In other cases they can be unpredictable. Similarly, the propagation of information through a protein, or the transitions of an ion channel amongst its various states, can follow a combination of random and deterministic rules.  Although ecological, protein, and ion channel networks describe biological systems on vastly different scales, the underlying mathematical description of random movement on a network are strikingly similar.  The interdisciplinary team working together on this grant -- an ecologist, a expert in protein dynamics, and a computational neuroscientst -- found ways to advance our understanding of how to describe and quantify systems involving random transitions on networks.

Ecological component: Many marine organisms have a juvenile stage in
which they float or swim in highly variable ocean currents. This means
the transport of immature marine organisms from one place to another is
unpredictable from year to year, including where they end up -- or
whether they get back to land at all.  This uncertainty has effects on
the long term growth of the population and on the evolution of traits
such as the size and number of offspring.  Prof. Snyder studied how the
long-term population growth of bicolor damselfish is affected by the
interaction of juvenile behavior and large ocean eddies off the Florida
Keys.  She also studied how ocean eddies affect the evolution of offspring size/number and the duration of the spawning period (in any coastal
organism).  This research sheds light on how some organisms cope with risky, uncertain, or changing environments.
Neuroscience component: Understanding the human brain remains one of the greatest unsolved problems of modern science.  Efforts underway, such as the Human Brain Project, involve building sophisticated computer models
that challenge even today's formidable computing resources.  Finding
efficient, but accurate, ways of simplifying the description of randomly
fluctuating ion channel currents is an important step towards
facilitating more detailed brain models.  Prof. Thomas, co-PI of the
project, and Dr. Schmidt, postdoctoral trainee, analyzed a novel
approach to simplifying the description of random fluctuations in ion
channel networks, called the ``stochastic shielding approximation." This
approximation is remarkably accurate, while speeding computational time
up to 10-fold.  Their work using mathematical ideas to analyze
stochastic shielding sheds light on why it works so well, and should
contribute to faster, more accurate computer models of brain function in
the future.

Protein component: The structural organization of proteins provides valuable information on their biological function, and numerous methods have appeared which analyze proteins as networks of amino acids connected by non-covalent contacts. Many of these methods are based on the local density of connections and aim to find groups of highly connected amino acids.
